awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Near-Real-Time High-Accuracy Musculoskeletal System Measurement and Analysis Instrument (SKELETALMI)
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The human musculoskeletal system consists of the skeleton, muscles, tendons, ligaments, joints, cartilage, and connective tissues. This system supports the body and enables it to implement all physical functions.  The human musculoskeletal system has been an active research subject for centuries due to the importance of this system to our daily lives. Disorders in any part of the human musculoskeletal system may seriously affect its function. It is considered one of the most prevalent, disabling and costly healthcare problems in the United States.  However, there remain numerous unknowns and challenges surrounding the human musculoskeletal system and musculoskeletal movements. For example, in the field of athletic training and exercise science, a common question is “how we can further improve an athlete’s or exerciser’s performance without causing injury?” In the footwear industry, designers are interested in knowing what factors affect comfort or performance when users are wearing shoes. In the injury prevention field, questions include: Why do humans have so many small bones in the wrist joints? What are the functions of these bones during functional activities? How do these bones reduce or increase the risk of being injured from slips and falls? Why do people develop back pains without doing significant physical work? What are the micro-level movements that occur at the lumbar spine? In digital human modeling and simulation, a general question is “how can we create more realistic simulations of human movements and personalized movement?”

Addressing these questions requires accurate characterization of living human body movement.  Existing surface-based systems cannot determine subtle but important differences of body movement due to the soft tissue artifacts.  This limitation severely compromise our understanding of musculoskeletal systems and prevent development of person-specific biomechanical research. The goal of this project is to develop a novel motion analysis system for measuring the live human body movement accurately and efficiently.

In this project, we have developed the methods for automatic segmentation, registration, and modeling.  We have proposed a novel multi-organ segmentation approach based on the method we developed last year.  We integrated deformable models and learning based techniques and conducted evaluations on a large set of 3D MR from longitudinal studies of hundreds of subjects.  We have segmented knee joint bones femur, tibia and patella.  In addition, we have also made significant progress on 2D/3D registration.  We have developed a feature-based and deformable model based registration method for kinematic analysis of joint bones. We have significantly improved the registration accuracy. We have developed a joint movement simulator for the validation study and successfully used to generate the realistic human joint movement.  We have also developed novel single camera based approach for quick tracking of human movement

Based on our work, we have published numerous top journal and conference papers.  Some papers have been published as a cover story and some received best paper awards.

The instrument will, we hope, make a contribution toward facilitating human movement analysis.  A wide variety of other applications, with the potential to improve the lives of the people with musculoskeletal disorders , could also benefit from the advances made through this project.

Through this project, many undergraduate and graduate students have had the opportunity to participate in human movement analysis, product design, and medical image analysis research.  This results in a unique generation of under-graduate and graduate researchers with a comprehensive knowledge of computational sciences, medical science, and product design.

Modified by: Kang Li
